title: Are there any members of the Medici family alive today? - Quora

response.answer_text: According to my own AncestryDNA testing, there still may be a blood line that exists, which stems from very distant cousins of mine (5th-8th cousins), who married some Medici’s (Battani), though there is a substantial gap in the genealogical line which I cannot explain, nor could Ancestry DNA. This may begin through illegitimate children of Alessandro Medici, who many believe is an illegitimate child of Pope Clement VII. His mother was a black slave in the House of Medici; his children, mothered by a mistress named Taddea Malaspina, has passed on the genetic DNA through their illegitimate children to Medici's that married into the French Royalty. This line possibly exists in Detroit, which could be explained as Detroit was a French Colony until the 1800‘s. Should there be any Medici’s in this line, they certainly have no right to any family assets, but they carry the family name and perhaps some of the recognition associated with the family line in terms of the social perception of having this last name. Keep in mind, today they may stand to be the 20+ great grandchildren of the First Duke of Florence. That is not a lot of blood, but it’s as potent as it might be for those living today if they truly are blood relatives.

I live in the United States but yes... My grandmother came here from Italy as a child in the early 1900s.... I am a Frantz due to my fathers last name, but my grandmothers maiden name along with my Great Grandfather and Great Grandmother is Medici. We are still here. I am actually trying to find out more information about our family Vinyard as I was told it had back taxes to be paid or we would lose the property.... I need help finding out how to contact the right people to try and pay the taxes and move back to Italy.... as I have been here in the US my whole life and would like to go back to were my family is from....  hopefully someone can help me out with finding the info to go back to Italy...?

Just so happened to play Crusader Kings II by Paradox Interactive, I think I know a speck on some Houses in Europe spanning from Early Middle Age to Late middle age. Although the House of Medici became prominent around 1500s(After Middle age), their influence in the peninsula of Italia(Duchy of Tuscany, Urbino, Florence…) didn't fade until around 1800s when Italy itself starts to lose its economical influence on Europe. France, Russia, and later Prussia became the Greater Power of Europe. The House of Medici, was essentially a family that became powerful because of its financial influence over the rich and prosperous regions in Italy. With current economical state of Italy in modern era, and that Medici didn't expand its influence beyond Europe, unlike the House of Rothschild, the House of Medici faded when their wealth and political power diminished. As far as recorded information suggests, I think there wouldn't be anymore descendent or any interested claimants. This is because there aren't anymore assets under the claim of the House of Medici. “Nothingness” cannot be claimed. FYI: The last decendent of the House of Medici, a Duke, died without a male heir in the 1737. With an Agnatic succession law, there won't be any legitimate female heir.

They’re descended from the female lines rather than the men who held power, but yes. The line starting with Cosimo died out before the Grand Dukes, then the Grand Dukes went extinct in 1737. However, there are a few other lines which can claim collateral descent. The most notably is probably this dude, Giovan Battista, prince of Ottajano. Among other things, Giovan argues that his family should have been given Tuscany after the previous dukes died out. There are also a few Medici descendants who hold lesser titles.

Medici, one of Italy's most celebrated clans. Known for writing cheques to Michelangelo, the Medici have of late been airing some dirty laundry as a handful of their descendants fall into a spat. "They are doing this without asking permission," said Marchese Giuliano Medici Tornaquinci, an elder of the family clan that now lives in Rome. "If they went into your chapel, into your tomb, and opened your family's graves, how would you feel?" Unfortunately for Marchese Tornaquinci, a distant relative, Prince Ottaviano de Medici, of a less distant Florentine branch of the family, is already deeply involved with the project and has given his consent. so, yes they do exist.. To read more go here…. https://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/05/07/1083911411065.html

I just learned today that my great x8 grandfather was Ferdinando I de' Medici and then obviously every Medici before him…. I was researching the family when I came across this question :) even if they have nothing now as the other who answered, I still think it’s awesome to be a descendant of the line.

I imagine so - although they may not be aware. It’s extremely difficult to stamp out a family line completely, there’s always a remote cousin hanging around somewhere. A second or third daughter who married out of the family and produced progeny under a different name … one of those might easily have started a dynasty of his own and forgotten the Medici name altogether. Or an illegitimate and forgotten child whose descendants still farm in the foothills of an Italian mountain. there’s bound to be a strain somewhere!

The last lineal descendant of the Medici line, Anna Maria Luisa, died childless in 1743. She was the sister of the last Grand Duke, Gian Gastone, also childless, who preceded her in death in 1737. She, the heiress, designated by her brother, bequeathed the Medici art collections from the Uffizi and Pitti palaces as well as the Medici palace to the Tuscan state with the proviso that they could never be removed from Florence. There could still be descendants from the collateral lines.

Hi I’m Cole Morea 17 year old from Michigan my grandmother told me that at her side of the family we have the De Medici bloodline flowing through our veins and to answer your question yes there are a couple even my family has it but not my mother thoe she is different but i am proud to say that yes there are ones still alive there is also prof that there is through a book of ancestry that is what my grand mother calls it anyway.

The Medici clan today traces its lineage along somewhat remotes lines, but holds itself out to be the "real deal." And, as always, they are fighting among themselves. Read more, here: Bad blood flows as Medicis go digging up their past Hope that helps.

As Queen Catharine de Medici bore 10 children, it seems probable that there should be descendants, though her three sons left no heirs. Marie de Medici married Louis XIII, and although the Bourbons presumably ended under the guillotine, there is contested DNA-evidence, that the Dutch poet Louis de Bourbon was a surviving descendant. It’s highly improbable that they would have been extinct, also given the fact that there were 3 Medici-popes.

Why yes, yes there is. I was looking them up after playing the old Assassin Creed Games (I am an addict) and apparently they still do exist, although not much of their bank did. They still upheld their name and live quiet lives like any other family. At least, according to the wikipedia article I read, so maybe I’m not the best source on that.

Define the word “members?” The Medici family was matriarchal in nature. Thus, the family always seemed to flow out into the patriarchal family that married into. Having said that, are there people who carry the mitochondrial DNA of the Medici's? I have no doubt!

The Medici family, also known as the House of Medici, first attained wealth and political power in Florence in the 13th century through its success in commerce and banking. Beginning in 1434 with the rise to power of Cosimo de’ Medici (or Cosimo the Elder), the family’s support of the arts and humanities made Florence into the cradle of the Renaissance, a cultural flowering rivaled only by that of ancient Greece. The Medicis produced four popes (Leo X, Clement VII, Pius IV and Leon XI), and their genes have been mixed into many of Europe’s royal families. The last Medici ruler died without a male heir in 1737, ending the family dynasty after almost three centuries.

There are. The Medici Family split is almost a dozen cadet families, one of which Medici Ottajano still exist today, have the title of Pricipi di Ottajano and are somehow related to the Bonaparte family, as well.

strangely we had a crooked mayor in Nice, Jacques Medecin, whose name is the translation of Medicis. The Medicis of the Renaissance were opposed to the Strozzi and guess what? the mayor of Nice is now Christian … Estrosi
I saw a reality program where a family named Di Medici was living in New York, so I’d say yes. As Katherine Di Medici was unkind to my relatives, I’m not sure how I feel about that.
Probably descendants. And probably are simply known as Signor Pietro Medici or Signorina Maria Medici living in Milan or Rome. Profession like lawyer or secretary.
Yes. See House of Medici - Wikipedia for details.
There are younger branches. What you have to remember, though, is that not all those called Medici, are related to the famous dynasty.
